text:
What year did you start housekeeping in eastern Canada? 1909

Where did you set up housekeeping? Prince Albert

Where had you been living before that? Saskatchewan

For how many people did you prepare meals? Six (including)

How far was it to your nearest store? Six miles

How often could a visit be made to the store?

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?

In what quantities did you buy it? Half a ton (around 360 lbs.)

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?

How much did you use groats flour?

Whole wheat flour?

Was flour milled locally? Yes, how far away? 50 miles

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?

What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal, whole wheat, Farina

Other?

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge?

How did you grind it?
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? ...........................................
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? .......................
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? ..................................
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? ....................................
At that price? ......................................................................................

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? .....................
Butter? ..............................................................................................
Eggs? ...............................................................................................
What was the price of butter? ......................................................... of eggs?
Did you pack eggs for winter? ......................................................... how?
Did you make butter? ................................................................. cheese?
What kind of cheese? ...........................................................................

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? ....................................
Beef, pork, hams & cured in the house.
How did you get fresh meat? .............................................................
How often did you get fresh meat? .....................................................
How did you preserve meat? .............................................................
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? .................................
If so what year was it organized? .....................................................
Did you use game? ................................................................. What kinds?
For how long? ..................................................................................
What part did fish play in the family diet? ...........................................
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? ................................................
Kinds? ...........................................................................................

6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? ................................ At what price? $1.00
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) ................................
Price? ...................... What other beverages were used? .......................

7. VEGETABLES AND VEGETABLE PRODUCTS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
Could you get potatoes at the store? ...........................................
If not, where from? ........................................................................
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes ........... Cabbages ........... Carrots ........... Onions ...........
Turnips ............. Beets ............. All for about $0.50
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? ................................
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? ................................
What weight? .............. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? ...
What was the price of prunes? ......................
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears,
apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)? all.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? ......................
peas? .......... corn? .......... beans? .......... Saskatoons? ..............
other foods? ..................................................................................

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? ....................
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? ............................
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? .............................
To what extent? ...........................................................................
Did you make your own vinegar? ..................................................

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) ... well (good)

How far was this water from your home? ... 250 yards

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ... barrel

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. ... no change

### Water Supply

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, cistern, dugout)

- Well (9.00)
- 250 gallons

If so, how was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank)

- Barrel

Flag arid water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? 

If you made your own, did you use lye? 

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle?

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? 

Where did you get your fuel? 

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

2 hours coal oil stove about 1911-1916

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates)

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made?

That year was it purchased?

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see enamel ware?

Aluminum?
13. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? (Give dates)

Have you not your fuel? (Give dates)

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own?

If you made your own, did you use lye? (Give dates)

Did you use a laundry soap? Did the grocer supply it?

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? (Give dates)

Have you not your fuel? (Give dates)

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own?

If you made your own, did you use lye? (Give dates)

Did you use a laundry soap? Did the grocer supply it?

15. KITCHEN APPLIANCES AND UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates)

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By when was your first cook stove used?

That year was it purchased?

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homesteader)

For preserving food (canning, water bath, crockery, other)

Then did you first see several years?

aluminum? (Give date)

retail in use.
16. **TRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS**

Mention any changes which you recall in the trappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Nearly all provisions were in bulk & a burlap house in paper bags.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? [REDACTED]... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time. [REDACTED]

Including [REDACTED] family on the [REDACTED].

2 women, 10 men, usually local relations,

no one over 40.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at that time. State the approximate monthly or yearly cost.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? Give the menu, list those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

Note - I do not consider myself a pioneer, having come to the farm which had been under cultivation for 20 years, in a Grace district, only 6 miles from C.P.R. main line, 187 from Regina; but am glad if any of these details may be of use in making a survey.

Helen M. Harrison

My husband, who came to Prince in 1895 went to buy a barrel of syrup, or a barrel of potatoes and apples, 7 weeks old bacon for week.
21. Then did you begin to rely on purchased foods and preserved foods instead of home grown and home preserved foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and storing foods in other parts during pioneer days in eastern Canada.

Please sign below:

Helen A. Harrison

Buy lumber, buy cattle & pasture in 1895 - travel to buy a team of oxen, to build a house, to work at least 3 months.
No. 613 S
